data.title: Do not open Welcome page on every reload
data.body:
testing #30722:

whenever the workbench reloads, the "Welcome" page opens again.

I think it is OK to be welcomed when VS Code starts anew, but a welcome for every reload is a bit too much.
And yes, I know that I can turn off the Welcome page, but I do not want to do this.

data.title: Debug should allow uri in DebugProtocol.Source
data.body:
In the Java language server, we can open classfiles with source attachment in the editor. It uses virtual documents with our own uri scheme. (e.g. jdt://contents/rt.jar/java.io/PrintStream.class).

We would like the debugger's stackframe location to return that uri too.
However, current debug protocol always expects file path. See the debugSource.ts https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/common/debugSource.ts

Ideally DebugProtocol.Source would also support a field `uri` that could be used instead of a path

data.title: [feature request] Ignore/Hiding lint errors

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
So I recently switched to VS Code and what I noticed is that having a global counter of file errors is handy. However, when say an error is not valid because the language doesn't support something yet, it is annoying to have these errors.

For example, in the CSS linter, there is an issue where the `@supports` rule isn't supported yet, or that the `/deep/` selector for Angular 4 isn't properly recognized. To make the errors go away I have to disable linting or (perhaps) disable rules that I don't want to disable. 

Also you can't limit the linter to only look at the existing file and get an overview of only that, so you are pretty limited to what you can and cannot do.

So my request is to extend the linting solution to allow errors to be hidden. Rightclick one and select `Hide error for this workspace` or something similar. And an option `only show errors for current file` would also be nice.

I also found out that it is pretty eager to validate my `node_modules` folder as well. I feel we also need a setting for workspace to specify linting exclusions (and/or globally)

data.title: Bottom panel height is maximized after resizing VSCode window

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have the bottom panel open at its default height
2. Resize the VSCode window, keep an eye on the "Maximise panel size" button for the bottom panel. Once you make the window small enough, it automatically switches to the "maximised" state.
3. Press the maximise button of the VSCode window.

The panel now stays at the maximised setting covering most of the code view. Where imo it should have never switched to the maximised setting in the first place.

It affects me because when my computer goes into standby it decides to resize VSCode to a size where the above described behavior is triggered (irregardless of window state). Im running at a resolution of 3840x2160. So that might have something to do with it.

data.title: File explorer that can be open in any window

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I was searching the issues and extensions and didn't succeed in finding something close.

Emacs has neat functionality that in normal window we can open a files explorer ([Dired](https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/emacs/Dired.html)) I find it very handy and more practical than explorer tree which can only be shown aside, which in turn takes valuable part of a screen most of the time

Short film showcasing how toggling between file explorer and typical file content view works in Emacs:

![2017-07-19 09 39 41](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/122434/28356091-06f20162-6c67-11e7-9bc6-6b716254cf98.gif)

In VSCode it could just open typical file explorer with focus on file that were open in given window, then traversing the file explorer with keyboard and specified shortcuts should work, pressing enter on file should just open the file in same window.

data.title: Relative Include Paths On Dependencies Not Being Detected With Intellisense
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: Version 1.14.1 (1.14.1)
- OS Version: 10.12.4 (16E195)

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Open a C++ project and set strict semantic checking for IntelliSense
2. Observer that include dependencies in other directories are unresolved due to the folder not being included explicitly.  However, from the perspective of the C++ compiler when it's processing the dependency, the include path of the file itself is available and thus the second order dependency is valid

For example for folder structure
```
/path
        inc_p.h
        /subpath
                        /inc1.h
                        /subsubpath/inc2.h
```

If inc_p.h includes "subpath/inc1.h" and inc1.h includes "subsubpath/inc2.h", inc_p.h will have a red squiggly error since inc2.h is not detected by IntelliSense despite the code compiling just fine.


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Save Workspace Only When You Click 'Closed Workspace' and Not When Closing VSCode

- OS Version: Windows 10

From [#30608](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30608#issuecomment-315092428)

@bpasero  said that the intent would be to ask to save Workspace when the VSCode closed. In my view, this request should only be made when I click on 'Closed Workspace.' (It will be very uncomfortable to be forced to save when closing)

It should work the way it is in the current version, and when I use a single folder. If I close the VSCode when I open it again it returns in the state that it was.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Git ignoring Proxy settings
data.body:
**- VSCode Version:** 1.14.1
**- OS Version:** Windows 10 Pro 1703

I work both on site and externally for a project and when on site I configure my system to run through the company proxy. This works fine for VS Code generally, I can access and use extensions, receive updates etc. But when I go to sync my work to the existing Git repository the connection times out and gives a: 

> git fetch
> fatal: unable to access 'https://our.git.repo': Failed to connect to our.git.repo port 443: Timed out

Some investigation with our network specialist reveals that the request being made when I sync is ignoring the proxy settings. I can access the repo directly through the browser just not in VS Code. 

My settings.json is currently set to: 

> "http.proxy": "http://our.proxy:port/",

have tried adding as well: 

> "https.proxy": "https://our.proxy:port/",


**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Set some functional proxy settings in User/Workspace settings.
2. Sync existing git repository. 

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Do not force to create a Workspace to use multiple folders
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0 Insiders ( 3cfa565 , Date 2017-07-17T05:15:33.728Z)
- OS Version: Windows 10

-- Sorry for the English, I used Google Translator --

From [#30608](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30608#issue-242682053)

But why am I forced to create a work area?

I simply want to add a second folder, without having to create a specific workspace

This window should have a third option, "Add only the folder".

![menu2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19866231/28346243-13534df0-6c06-11e7-9e11-955c6cc84e5d.png)

That is, the options would be: "New Workspace", "Add only the folder", "Cancel".


Something very similar, seen in @alefragnani [commentary](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/396#issuecomment-315627805)

> It shouldn't force to create a workspace just to add another folder to the current window. It should just add the new folder in the tree, and leave the newly created workspace as an internal info. If the user decides to save the workspace, then the workspace is really created. And even if I don't save the workspace, while reopening the top-folder, it would remember my temporary workspace_ and open the other folders as well, just like it remembers the opened files when you open a folder today.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

From [comment](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30608#issuecomment-315509349) by @bpasero
